reasoning: 1. Circle of Competence: I’ve long steered clear of the auto business—too cyclical, capital‐intensive and outside my wheelhouse. Like trying to read tea leaves, I don’t pretend to understand the intricacies of battery chemistry and self-driving software. 2. Moat: Tesla’s brand shines like a beacon, but folks soon discover building cars at scale is a commodity game. Legacy automakers and new entrants are closing the gap on batteries and autonomy. That moat feels more like chicken wire than concrete. 3. Management: Elon Musk is a lightning rod—charismatic, visionary, but prone to distraction across multiple ventures. I prefer CEOs who think like owners and allocate capital conservatively. 4. Financial Health: Tesla has generated profits lately, yet it bears significant debt and faces margin pressure amid stiff competition and raw-material swings. I want a fortress balance sheet with consistent free cash flow. 5. Valuation: At nosebleed multiples, you’re paying for every ounce of future optimism. My rule is: pay a reasonable price for a wonderful business. Tesla trades like the world’s favorite rumor. 6. Long-Term Prospects: Electric vehicles will prosper, but so will dozens of competitors. Without a durable cost or distribution moat, returns may disappoint. 7. Relative Opportunity: I’d rather own BYD at sensible valuations, Coca-Cola, or Berkshire’s insurance franchises. In my book, it’s better to hold quality at a fair price than chase a fair business at a rich price. So the answer here is no.
